text:
```xml ~/Downloads/google.com!houseofeducation.io!1738627200!1738713599.xml google.com noreply-dmarc-support@google.com https://support.google.com/a/answer/2466580 14760446749479477594 1738627200 1738713599 houseofeducation.io r r

reject

reject 100 reject 141.193.32.11 5 none pass pass mail.houseofeducation.io mail.houseofeducation.io pass email eu.mailgun.org pass krs2 mail.houseofeducation.io pass 185.250.239.4 1 none pass pass mail.houseofeducation.io mail.houseofeducation.io pass email mail.houseofeducation.io pass 185.250.239.4 6 none pass pass mail.houseofeducation.io mail.houseofeducation.io pass email eu.mailgun.org pass krs2 mail.houseofeducation.io pass ``` What does this DMARC report mean? This DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) report from Google shows email authentication results for the domain houseofeducation.io. Let's break down the key points: 1. Report Overview: - It's from Google (google.com) - Covers a specific 24-hour period - The domain being reported on is houseofeducation.io 2. Policy Settings: - The domain has a strict DMARC policy (p=reject) - Both DKIM and SPF are set to "relaxed" mode (r) - The policy is applied to 100% of emails (pct=100) 3. Email Activity: - Emails were sent from two IP addresses: * 141.193.32.11 (5 messages) * 185.250.239.4 (7 messages total: 1 + 6) 4. Authentication Results: - All messages PASSED both DKIM and SPF checks - The emails are using both houseofeducation.io and eu.mailgun.org (indicating Mailgun is being used as an email service provider) - All messages had proper alignment with the header_from domain The good news is that all emails are properly authenticated and aligned with the domain's DMARC policy. There were no failures or suspicious activities reported, indicating that the email infrastructure is correctly configured and working as intended. This is exactly what you want to see in a DMARC report - all messages passing authentication checks with no rejected or quarantined emails.
